column4: Is there a command I can run in Terminal or something else I can do to reset the volume settings? After installing GnomeRadio, tvtime and gradio and GnomeRadio have horrible sound, full of static and very loud. The sound used to be great.
alsamixer

ok, I have alsamixer up, do you have any recommendations on where to set each setting? The sound from tvtime and GnomeRadio are terrible now. What would GnomeRadio have changed to make the sound this way?
I don't know tv
ok, Thanks
no DNS?
can you go to web by IP?
No
can you ping?
to test, sudo route -n
do you have a reasonable route table?

no, I can't do anything, but yet I know I am connected because when I pick up the phone while connected I hear the handshake. Also, I have the Modem and Network Monitors on the panel and the Network Monitor becomes active, but the Modem Monitor shows Not Connected.
stop pppd, try wvdial
I can't tried sudo route -n yet because I am on the Internet on another computer right now. I tried wvdial, it always says connected and then it says carrier signal lost.
did you try StupidMode with wvdial? it works for many
how do I get to StupidMode with wvdial
in your /etc/wvdial.conf
Do you mean entering the phone, user name, password etc. or is there something else I add to that file to get to StupidMode?
no, you first try wvdialconf to generate a wvdial.conf, then, you edit it, you can " man wvdial.conf "
wvdialconf did not generate one, it couldn't find the modem. I edited wvdial.conf myself and entered the info myself.
you can make a link to /dev/modem
I have already done that, it was part of the steps of installing the modem. It is an Intel 537EP Internal Modem. It worked great on Breezy, no problems at all.
I remember wvdial seeks /dev/modem
It didn't find the modem though, but System => Administration => Networking autodetected the modem after I compiled and installed the drivers.
